On the Comparison of Colourblind with ordinary vision by means 
of observations with coloured papers. 

In March 1859 I obtained a set of observations by 
Mr Simpson of the relations between 6 coloured papers 
as seen by him. The colours were - Vermillion (V), Ultramarine (U), 
Emerald Green (G), Ivory Black (B), Snow White (W), and pale Chrome Yellow 
(Y). These 6 colours afford 15 colour=blind equations, since 4 colours 
enter into each equation. 14 of these were observed by Mr Simpson 
and from these I deduced three equations <s>from<\s>  giving the relation 
of the three standards (V), (U) (G) to the <s>three<\s> other colours according 
to his kind of vision. From these three equations I then 
deduced 15 equations, admitting of comparison with the observed 
equations, and necessarily consistent in themselves. 
The comparison of these equations furnishes a test of the truth of 
the theory that the colour blind see by means of two colour=sensations 
and that therefore every colour may be expressed in terms of <u>two<\u> 
given colours, just as in ordinary vision it may be expressed in 
terms of three <s>sensations<\s> given colours. The one set of equations 
are each the result of a single observation, the other set are 
deduced from three equations in accordance with this theory and 
the two sets agree to within an average error = 2.1.* 
But, according to our theory, colour=blind vision is not only 
dichromic, but the two elements of colour are identical with 
two of the three elements of colour as seen by the ordinary 
eye, so that it differs from ordinary vision only in being
